text: (soft music)
- Flutter Entertainment is one

of the world's largest online
sports and gaming providers.

And our mission is to
bring excitement to life
to our 14 million customers
in a safe, responsible, and stable way.

What's quite unique about our
data challenge is on one hand,

the very large volume of
data that we need to acquire,
and on the other hand,

the very low latency with
which we need to process it
to drive some of our critical services.

So the Redshift team have
delivered innovations
of previous years,

such as the separation
of storage from compute.

So we can keep acquiring
all that volume of data

but also allowing us to scale
the compute independently

and through things like
concurrency scaling to scale
up and down as needed.

So over the last number of
years, we've been acquiring more

and more data from pretty
much any source system

that we can perceive the value
to be data from that source,
whether it's covering onsite

or offsite interactions,
transaction, and behavioral data.
At the same time,

our stakeholders also
wanted to implement more
and more complex solutions that have gone
from originally batched to intra day
to now real time execution.

So this combination of
volume and latency together

creates an ongoing challenge
for me and my team.

Today we can process
almost 4 million queries

across a data set of over
150 terabytes on the cluster.
This means that as our query

and data volumes have
grown, we've been able to
maintain a consistent end user experience.

We consider our technical account
manager to be an extension
of our own team who work with us to,

really anticipate problems and
help us plan for big events
rather than just responding to incidents
after they've happened.

And we're also an early adopter
of AWS services and features

and have enterprise
support with us, gives us

that confidence to basically
try these things early

knowing that we'll be
supported along the way.
Any customer that's using a broad range

of AWS services, and
really is a low tolerance

for any post-production
instance should really
consider enterprise support.
Redshift has given us the ability to

process the data volumes and
service our stakeholders needs
in a way that we just could not have done

if we were still running
on on-premise solutions.
We see Redshift data sharing
as the key feature to enable us to move
to our next evolution of our platform.
(upbeat music)
